title: 108_hr2697
content: The "Caring Family Act of 2003" provides an additional personal exemption for dependents with long-term care needs in the taxpayer's home under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This amendment allows for an exemption of the applicable amount for each qualified family member of the taxpayer. The "Caring Family Act of 2003" provides an additional personal exemption for qualified family members of the taxpayer based on the applicable amount for each taxable year. The applicable amounts range from $500 to $2,500 for different calendar years, with specific criteria for defining a qualified family member. The "Caring Family Act of 2003" offers an extra personal exemption for qualified family members of the taxpayer, including those aged 60 or older, individuals with long-term care needs, and those living with the taxpayer for more than half of the year. An individual with long-term care needs is certified by a physician for at least 180 consecutive days. An individual with long-term care needs is certified by a physician for at least 180 consecutive days as unable to perform certain daily activities without assistance or supervision for health and safety. The taxpayer must include the name and TIN of the qualified family member, as well as the name and TIN of the certifying physician, on their tax return to claim an exemption for a family member unable to engage in age-appropriate activities. The text discusses special rules and conforming amendments related to tax code sections 151 and 3402. Amendments are made to various sections of the tax code, replacing references to section 151(d) with section 151(e). The effective date for these changes is for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2002.
